results.title: The Sopranos. Season 4
results.creator_credit: Alan Taylor, Allen Coulter, Daniel Attias, Henry J. Bronchtein, Jack Bender, James Hayman, John Patterson, Steve Buscemi, Tim Van Patten, David Chase, Ilene Landress, Brad Grey Television, Chase Films and Home Box Office
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Sopranos”.
Season four of this award-winning television series created by David Chase. The dark exploration of masculinity, abuse and violence which is central to this series exemplifies what is unique to The Sopranos: terrific writing, outstanding performances and a daring audacity to fully explore the brutality of contemporary culture in the US. The mores and ethics of organised crime seem an apt metaphor for the capitalist system. Ep 1 “For all debts public and private” Tony tries to raise cash for investments, whilst Carmela pushes for traditional insurance. Uncle Junior frets about his impending trial. Ep 2 “No show” With Paulie behind bars, Christopher is assigned his turf. Meadow considers taking a year off college. Ep 3 “Christopher” The first Soprano trial in 16 years commences; Italian pride causes an array of troubles. Ep 4 “The Weight” Johnny Sack embarks on a bloody vendetta; Carmela develops a close relationship with Furio, encountering Tony problems. Ep 5 “Pie o my” Carmela and Tony continue to disagree over the finances; Uncle Junior faces problems in court. Ep 6 “Everybody hurts” Tony gives greater responsibility to Christopher; Meadow joins the right side of the law. Ep 7 “Watching too much television” Tony and the gang throw a release-party for Paulie. Furio finds himself attracted to Carmela. Ep 8 “Mergers & acquisitions” Tony meets an attractive art dealer; Paulie tries to integrate his mother into her nursing home; Carmela discovers a new source of income. Ep 9 “Whoever did this” Uncle Junior develops a new defence strategy; Tony brings Svetlana back into their lives; tragedy strikes Ralph’s son. Ep 10 “The Strong, silent type” Tony tracks down Ralph; Furio struggles with his feelings for Carmela; Christopher’s heroin addiction turns catastrophic. Ep 11 “Calling all cars” Dreams persue Tony through the night; Tony contemplates business decisions; Dr Melfi works on the undercurrents of Tony’s dreams but he wants out. Ep 12 “Eloise” Tony haggles over profits; Paulie’s loyalty is called into question. Ep 13 “Whitecaps” Tony battles to keep the family together.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alan Taylor, Allen Coulter, Daniel Attias, Henry J. Bronchtein, Jack Bender, James Hayman, John Patterson, Steve Buscemi, Tim Van Patten, David Chase, Ilene Landress, Brad Grey Television, Chase Films and Home Box Office

results.title: The Sopranos. Season 3 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Allen Coulter, Daniel Attias, Henry J. Bronchtein, Jack Bender, John Patterson, Steve Buscemi, Tim Van Patten, David Chase, Ilene Landress, Brad Grey Television, Chase Films and Home Box Office
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Sopranos”.
The third season of this award-winning television series finds the Soprano family going about their business unaware that the FBI have begun a covert surveillance of their every move. But as the series progresses, the ever watchful eye of the Feds becomes less important than the personal experiences of the New Jersey crime family. Tony Soprano (James Gandolfini) is still in therapy and though he is still baiting psychoanalyst Dr. Melfi (Lorraine Bracco), he is getting closer to understanding the source of his anxiety attacks: they are triggered by memories of his violent childhood. But with the death of his mother, Livia (Nancy Marchand), Tony has to deal with the twin demons of rage and guilt. Tony also has to deal with his daughter Meadow’s awakening sexuality (including her falling in love with a black man) as well as with the spiritual angst of his wife, Carmella (Edie Falco), who is increasingly disturbed by the ethical implications of her being a partner to a mobster. It’s only when he meets the beautiful Gloria (Annabella Sciorra) that things start looking up for Tony, but soon, in true Soprano’s style, her emotional instability creates a dangerous domestic situation for him. Outstanding episodes in this series include “Employee of the month”, which deals with the rape of Dr. Melfi, the black comedy of “Pine barrens”, directed by Steve Buscemi, and the horrifying violence of “University” which features the abusive relationship between a mobster and one of the strippers at the Bada Bing. The dark exploration of masculinity, abuse and violence which is central to this episode exemplifies what is unique to The Sopranos: terrific writing, outstanding performances and a daring audacity to fully explore the brutality of contemporary culture. The mores and ethics of organised crime seem an apt metaphor for the contemporary world.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Allen Coulter, Daniel Attias, Henry J. Bronchtein, Jack Bender, John Patterson, Steve Buscemi, Tim Van Patten, David Chase, Ilene Landress, Brad Grey Television, Chase Films and Home Box Office

results.title: The Sopranos. Season 2 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Allen Coulter, Henry J. Bronchtein, John Patterson, Lee Tamahori, Martin Bruestle, Tim Van Patten, Ilene Landress, Brillstein-Grey Entertainment, Chase Films and Home Box Office
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Sopranos”.
In the second series of the outstanding television series about the day to day realities of a New Jersey Mafia family, we find that Tony Soprano (James Gandolfini) is still prone to bouts of existential despair while at the same time having to be the boss-man of an organised crime family. While dealing with the running of his myriad operations Tony also has to keep the facts of his adulterous affairs from his suspicious wife, Carmella (Edie Falco) and make sure that his increasingly rebellious children don’t undermine him. It is one of the major achievements of the series that though the criminal and violent world it portrays is specific, unique and tinged with the romanticism of Golden Age Hollywood representations of crime and gangsters, it nevertheless manages to make Tony’s ethical and psychological choices resonate with the everyday realities of the viewer’s life. In Series Two, Tony returns to his psychiatrist and also returns to the family home in Naples. This episode, “Commendatori” is a series highlight, revolving around the glaring discrepancies between the Italo-American conceptions of the “old country” and the realities of contemporary Europe. Other outstanding episodes in series two include “D-Girl” where Christopher (Michael Imperioli) finds hidden talents as an actor and “Knight in white satin armour” where the tensions between Janie, Ritchie and Tony resolve in a violent and unexpected manner. But every episode in this adult cynical series is of excellent value.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Allen Coulter, Henry J. Bronchtein, John Patterson, Lee Tamahori, Martin Bruestle, Tim Van Patten, Ilene Landress, Brillstein-Grey Entertainment, Chase Films and Home Box Office

results.title: The Sopranos
results.creator_credit: Alan Taylor, Allen Coulter, Andy Wolk, Daniel Attias, David Chase, John Patterson, Lorraine Senna, Matthew Penn, Nick Gomez, Tim Van Patten, Ilene Landress, Brillstein-Grey Entertainment, Chase Films and Home Box Office
results.brief_description: Multi-Emmy Award winning series which brilliantly portrays the everyday lives of a New Jersey crime family. Tony Soprano (James Gandolfini), though ostensibly in the Waste Management business is really one of the heads of a large Mafia family. With a consistently brilliant cast, tough and witty writing and a complex examination of materialism and contemporary American society, “The Sopranos” manages to create an ambiguous moral epic out of its study of power, corruption and money. Violent and uncompromising, the series delivers a narrative sweep that has the breadth of the classical nineteenth century novel but its language, vision and cynicism plants it firmly in the twenty-first. Created by David Chase and featuring direction by noted independent directors such as Nick Gomez, “The Sopranos” deserves the acclaim heaped upon it. In its moral complexity, insight and daring it leaves the products of the Hollywood motion picture industry for dead.

results.title: The Sopranos. Season 1 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Alan Taylor, Allen Coulter, Andy Wolk, Daniel Attias, David Chase, John Patterson, Lorraine Senna, Matthew Penn, Nick Gomez, Tim Van Patten, Ilene Landress, Brillstein-Grey Entertainment, Chase Films and Home Box Office
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Sopranos”.
The first season of the multi-Emmy Award winning series which brilliantly portrays the everyday lives of a New Jersey crime family. Tony Soprano (James Gandolfini), though ostensibly in the Waste Management business is really one of the heads of a large Mafia family. When the series begins he is disturbed by the on-set of a mid-life crisis in which the arrival of a nest of ducks in the family swimming pool precipitates dizzy-spells and increasingly disturbing dreams. He begins secret sessions with a psychiatrist, played by Lorraine Bracco, in which he slowly divulges the issues in his life. They include dealing with the suspicions of his intelligent Catholic wife, Carmella (Edie Falco); the traumas of seeing his daughter, Meadow (Jamie-Lynn Sigler), leave adolescence behind and prepare for College; and his concerns with his slacker son, Anthony Junior (Robert Iler). On top of this he has to deal with the constant undermining by his tough-bitch mother (Nancy Marchand) and the wheeling and dealing of his uncle, Junior (Dominic Chianese). Its only when he is with his “boys”, the “capos” that form his Mafia Crew - Paulie (Tony Sirico), Christopher (Michael Imperioli) and Silvio (Steven Van Zandt) - that Tony can relax. But even then, business always intrudes … With a consistently brilliant cast, tough and witty writing and a complex examination of materialism and contemporary American society, “The Sopranos” manages to create an ambiguous moral epic out of its study of power, corruption and money. Violent and uncompromising, the series delivers a narrative sweep that has the breadth of the classical nineteenth century novel but its language, vision and cynicism plants it firmly in the twenty-first. Created by David Chase and featuring direction by noted independent directors such as Nick Gomez, “The Sopranos” deserves the acclaim heaped upon it. In its moral complexity, insight and daring it leaves the products of the Hollywood motion picture industry for dead.

results.title: I Still know what you did last summer
results.creator_credit: Danny Cannon, Neal H. Moritz and Global Entertainment Productions
results.brief_description: Producer of “I know what you did last summer” Neal H. Moritz commented that “I Know” was positioned perfectly with the success of “Scream”, “Party of five” and “Buffy the Vampire Slayer.” Its sequel, “I still know what you did last summer,” without such support in its marketing campaign, was left to prove itself in a sea of teen horror films, all trailing in the wake of “Scream.” “I Still know” reunites us with our heroine, Julie James (Jennifer Love Hewitt), at university, far away from Southport where the horrors of last summer (and the summer before that), took place. The nightmares of the meat-hook-wielding fisherman are preventing Julie from putting the brutal murder of her best friend, Helen (Sarah Michelle Gellar), behind her. Luckily, Julie has made a new best friend, Karla (Brandy), who has won a trip to the Bahamas and convinces Julie to go with her and some other friends. They arrive only to discover that it’s the off-peak season and, with the exception of ‘marginally trained off-season staff’, they are alone on the island. Julie’s nightmares become a reality upon discovering the fisherman is on the island seeking his revenge. Julie is forced to fess up to her friends about her tormented past as they struggle for their lives knowing they are caught in total isolation. Refreshingly, “I Still know” has subscribed to the new paradigm of teen horror, whereby the protagonist teen character is given personality and a surname. With a supporting cast that is less disposable than the teenager characters of slasher films of the past, “I Still know” is more suspenseful and more frightening, and a horror film that can stand on its own merit. Cast includes: Jennifer Love Hewitt, Brandy, Freddy Prinze Jr., Mekhi Phifer, Muse Watson.

results.title: Whore
results.creator_credit: Ken Russell, Dan Ireland, Ronaldo Vasconcellos and Trimark Pictures
results.brief_description: Whore tells the story of one night in the life of a prostitute. Liz, (Theresa Russell) is a street wise hooker who has seen it all and done it all. In contrast to “Pretty Woman”, this film does not glamorise prostitution. This is a brash, vulgar depiction of the profession. Although exploitative and titillating in itself, it does raise issues often overlooked in more romantic interpretations, including legalisation, safe sex, drug abuse and the relationship between sex and power.

results.title: The Ring within [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Dan Bigras, Eric Michel and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Dan Bigras, Canadian singer and filmmaker, features in his own documentary along with his extreme fighter friends, Charles Ali Nestor (27 y.o.), David Loiseau (21 y.o.) and Steve Vigneault (22 y.o.) to demonstrate that an outlet can be found for those who find themselves battling with self-destructive impulses or overwhelming uncontrollable anger and rage. Where Bigras uses singing and song-writing as his outlet, his friends prefer to channel their energies into martial arts and extreme fighting as a way of rebuilding their lives. It would seem a common thread runs through the lives of each of these young men as they tell their stories of an unhappy childhood, bullying, teenage gangs, violence and family break-down. But the frankness and honesty in their personal tales and the friendship, loyalty and support between the four men in their collective struggle to transform their anger into a rage for life is what really defines this film, not the fighting scenes - their courage is to be admired. Features interviews with families, friends, sporting personnel and other extreme fighters and includes graphic coverage of bouts from competition fights and training sessions. In English and French with English subtitles. WARNING: CONTAINS GRAPHIC IMAGES OF EXTREME FIGHT SCENES.

Features interviews with families, friends, sporting personnel and other extreme fighters and includes graphic coverage of bouts from competition fights and training sessions. In English and French with English subtitles. WARNING: CONTAINS GRAPHIC IMAGES OF EXTREME FIGHT SCENES.
description_for_label: Dan Bigras, Canadian singer and filmmaker, features in his own documentary along with his extreme fighter friends, Charles Ali Nestor (27 y.o.), David Loiseau (21 y.o.) and Steve Vigneault (22 y.o.) to demonstrate that an outlet can be found for those who find themselves battling with self-destructive impulses or overwhelming uncontrollable anger and rage. Where Bigras uses singing and song-writing as his outlet, his friends prefer to channel their energies into martial arts and extreme fighting as a way of rebuilding their lives. It would seem a common thread runs through the lives of each of these young men as they tell their stories of an unhappy childhood, bullying, teenage gangs, violence and family break-down. But the frankness and honesty in their personal tales and the friendship, loyalty and support between the four men in their collective struggle to transform their anger into a rage for life is what really defines this film, not the fighting scenes - their courage is to be admired. Features interviews with families, friends, sporting personnel and other extreme fighters and includes graphic coverage of bouts from competition fights and training sessions. In English and French with English subtitles. WARNING: CONTAINS GRAPHIC IMAGES OF EXTREME FIGHT SCENES.

results.title: More Winners : His Master's Ghost
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, Margaret McDonald and Steve Steve Jodrell
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘More Winners’.
A vacation music camp at an old country estate brings together a group of children, not all of whom have come with music foremost in their minds. The estate has an air of mystery about it and when mention is made of a live-in ghost, some of the children, especially Flea, become fascinated. Flea’s obsession in tracking down the ghost and playing practical jokes leads him into constant trouble with the teachers. Meanwhile, Jason, a rather serious boy is, against some purist opposition, trying to get his Concerto for the Rock Group and Orchestra, which has a very difficult solo passage, played in the final concert. Between these two stories floats the estate’s caretaker, a figure of mystery and fascination. Rated: G
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Children’s Television Foundation, Margaret McDonald and Steve Steve Jodrell

results.title: More Winners : Second Childhood
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, Jane Ballantyne and Mario Andreacchio
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘More Winners”.
At school, Mark meets Annie who believes she is the reincarnation of Australia’s most famous racehorse - Phar Lap. Mark is fascinated by the concept of being someone else and becomes convinced he is the reincarnation of Henry Ford. His friends at school also get into the act believing they were Queen Victoria and Albert Einstein. At first they revel in their new identities especially when a major new school assignment is to research the life of a prominent historical figure. When their research reveals that their past lives were collectively responsible for quite a few of the world’s current problems, the children set out on a daring mission to make up for what they have done. Rated: G
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Children’s Television Foundation, Jane Ballantyne and Mario Andreacchio
